Fields.DialogueText: Hello in there! You're Steregushchy, I presume?
*KNOCK*
Pardon me, but are you Steregushchy?
Zdravstvuyte. You must be the new kapitan? My apologies - when door is closed on my observatoriya, it is difficult to hear outside.

Fields.MenuText: This is your observatory? I was wondering what this glass pod was doing in the middle of the deck.
What kind of observatory is this if you can't even detect anyone approaching?
I didn't mean to interrupt your work, but I just wanted to introduce myself.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan! Is it not beautiful?
*CREEEAK*
It is not meant for detecting those approaching from our deck, Kapitan.
I am always keeping watch, Kapitan. If interruption really is required, now is as good a time as any.
The craftsmanship is truly impressive!
So what is the purpose of this observatory, anyway?
Oh, well, pardon the interruption...
I constructed the observatoriya to improve the surveillance capabilities of my vessel. With my binokl and listening devices, I can detect the enemy approaching from above and below.
I see! This should be very useful for the war effort.
*BOOM*
Oy! Rusalki attacking, Kapitan! When you interrupt my surveillance, we are vulnerable to surprise!
My apologies, Steregushchy! Let's get our guns firing back at those Morganas!
Da, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Apologies again for interrupting your surveillance the other day, Steregushchy. Those Morganas snuck up on us while I was introducing myself.
Nichevo strashnava. You are the kapitan, Kapitan. It is your job to interrupt other people while they are working.
Well, I had never thought about it that way before...
We must always be watching to gain the advantage before we meet the enemy, Kapitan.
That's true. Acting a few seconds faster can completely turn the tide of a battle.
Da, Kapitan. It is good you understand. That is why my main priority now is to upgrade the capabilities of my observatoriya.

Fields.MenuText: "Steregushchy" does mean "Watchful," so it's not surprising that spying on things is your priority.
You've got a lot of telescopes, listening devices, and charts in there. Isn't all that enough?
It's so cluttered with all the tools and maps you've got. Maybe tidying up should be the first thing to do?

Fields.DialogueText: I am not "spying," Kapitan. I am observing to maintain my awareness of situation around us.
There is always potential for improvement, Kapitan - especially concerning surveillance technology.
Everything in my observatoriya is in the right place, Kapitan. Maybe you do not understand my organization system, but it has no need to change.
The big problem now is that Soviet standard issue equipment is no good. Soviet binokl barely see the flag on top of the flagpole from here!
If that's the case, we can always request better equipment from the Neutrality Fleet.
Nyet, Kapitan. Only fools wait for help from others. I will make better surveillance equipment myself. I have already started plans for the biggest observation binokl in the Red Fleet's history!
*GUNFIRE*
Rusalki! Kapitan, you are always interrupting surveillance and giving the advantage to the enemy!
Hey, at least we shot first this time!
@BATTLE
Rusalki ahead, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
So tell me more about these new observation binoculars you're designing, Steregushchy.
Our surveillance capabilities are limited by poor quality equipment, Kapitan. I will construct the biggest binokl in history of Red Fleet so we can better detect enemy ships and bombers.
That does sound useful, but can you really build something like that all by yourself?
Da, Kapitan! I have been studying methods of glass making and metalworking from these books here. I will construct my own lenses and teleskop tubes.

Fields.MenuText: That's impressive! You're teaching yourself glassblowing and metalworking just by reading books?
Whatever you make is bound to be better than standard issue Soviet gear...

Fields.DialogueText: All money goes to the Red Army. The Navy gets nothing!
It is possible to learn anything if you make enough effort, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: It might be difficult to build something as ambitious as that on board a ship...

Fields.DialogueText: It presents certain challenges, Kapitan, but they can be overcome with good planning.
You've got a great idea, but it still doesn't sound like it's going to be easy.
Finding the right materials will be difficult, Kapitan, but I think construction will be easy!
Hmm... we'll have to see about that!
*KNOCK*
Steregushchy! It's me - the Captain!
*CREEEAK*
Zdraste, Kapitan.
Steregushchy, you look exhausted! When was the last time you slept?
I have been on watch now for... 17 hours...
You should get some sleep! The sailors run their own watch rotation, so keeping watch isn't even your responsibility.
As long as I have coffee, I am okay, Kapitan. Now - why are you interrupting my work this time?
A sailor delivered a message to the bridge saying you wanted to speak with me. I made it over here as soon as I could...
Ah yes, I did call for you, Kapitan! Sorry - sometimes it is hard to remember things when I have been on watch for a long time...

Fields.MenuText: You really take this surveillance thing seriously, don't you?
You're no good on watch if you're too tired to remember anything.
You've been sitting inside your observatory for 17 hours? Have you even gotten up to use the head?

Fields.DialogueText: We are at war, Kapitan! The enemy is out there, and we need to know what they are doing.
I will make another cup of coffee, Kapitan. It keeps me awake... and maybe helps the memory a little bit.
That is a very private question to be asking Comrade of the Fleet, Kapitan! I have ways of solving such problems. It is not your concern.
Right. So anyway, why did you want to speak with me?
We need to chart course to Italiya, then to Rossiya, Kapitan. Construction of binokl requires silica sand from Italiya, and steel from Matushka Rossiya.
There's heavy Morgana activity in both of those areas, Steregushchy. That's putting the ship and crew at a lot of risk just to run errands for your little binocular project...
It is not a little binokl project, Kapitan! They will be the biggest binokl in the history of the Red Fleet!
*BOOM*
The Kapitan interrupts surveillance yet again! Boyevyye stantsii!
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
Those Morganas got the jump on us again, Steregushchy! Return fire!
Standard issue Soviet binokl are worthless at finding Rusalki first, Kapitan!
*GUNFIRE*
@BATTLE
We are getting ambushed by the Morganas more often than not lately, aren't we?
Da, Kapitan. I think you are beginning to realize our weakness in surveillance equipment.
Yes, you're right. If we were better at spotting the Morganas on the horizon, we could get the upper hand in battle more often.
Does this mean you will help with my binokl project, Kapitan? I will build the biggest binokl in the history of the Red Fleet!

Fields.MenuText: Yes. I was wrong to doubt you. You understand the needs of the ship more than anyone.
We could improve a lot of things on the ship, and better observation equipment certainly wouldn't hurt.
We can sail anywhere as long as we're accomplishing our mission of sinking Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. The crew cannot fire at the enemy if they cannot see!
Da, Kapitan. It would also be good to improve the guns, torpedoes, radios... but observation is our primary deficiency!
We will sink many more Rusalki when we have improved our surveillance capabilities, Kapitan!
So you want to set a course for Italy?
Da, Kapitan. We need high quality silica sand from Italiya to make glass lenses for binokl.
Sounds like a good excuse for a Mediterranean cruise, Steregushchy!
Steregushchy, we've set course for Italy so we can get the silica sand you need to make your binocular lenses.
Vy ochen' dobry. You will not regret supporting my plan, Kapitan.
Have you been getting enough sleep? You look pretty tired again.
Five cups of coffee today - no problem, Kapitan. I am keeping watch while studying up on glass making.

Fields.MenuText: I'm impressed that you're actually teaching yourself how to make glass for these binocular lenses!
You wouldn't need so much coffee if you just got more sleep.
Can you really keep watch while reading a book at the same time?

Fields.DialogueText: Better to find solutions yourself than wait for help that never comes, Kapitan!
Da, Kapitan, but this book will not read itself!
Of course, Kapitan! We Comrades of the Fleet know the virtue of doing many things at once!
This book makes glassmaking seem more complicated than I'd expected, though! Constructing binokl lens may be more difficult than I thought...
Well, you seem pretty sharp, Steregushchy, so I'm sure you'll figure it out. Don't give up before you've even tried!
Da, Kapitan, you're right!
*BOOM*
Oy! Rusalki again, Kapitan! Luckily their shooting is not so accurate!
We can't keep getting ambushed like this! Those Morganas are going to get a lucky shot in one of these days!
@BATTLE
It'll be a while until we reach Italy, Steregushchy.
No problem, Kapitan! I am using the time to read my books, so I will be an expert on glass making once we get sand in Italiya.
Nice to hear you're making productive use of your time.
Da, Kapitan. I appreciate your support for my  binokl project. Most kapitany in the Red Fleet do not like suggestions!
To say thank you, I made a pot of coffee - please have a drink with me, Kapitan!
Why thank you, Steregushchy! This coffee smells pretty strong, but I suppose I could use a little pick-me-up...

Fields.MenuText: Wow! This coffee is fantastic! It's so rich without being too bitter.
Woah! This coffee is really strong! How do you ever fall asleep after drinking this?
It smells like alcohol - you didn't pour any vodka in this coffee, did you?

Fields.DialogueText: It is Turkish-style coffee, Kapitan. By grinding beans finely, the greatest amount of caffeine is made available!
Coffee is not for afternoon naps, Kapitan!
Nyet, Kapitan! Vodka does not belong in coffee! Alcohol is no help when trying to keep watch.
Well, I do appreciate you coming all the way to the bridge to share your coffee with me. Is anyone keeping watch in your observatory, though?
I decided to take a break from my surveillance and reading to make a short visit to you, Kapitan - so I put twenty extra sailors on watch to help look for Rusalki.
Twenty? That seems like a lot! Where did you even find that many extra sailors?
It is easy to make sailors volunteer when the Comrade of Fleet asks nicely... and shows a little leg, Kapitan.
Here I was thinking you were just book-smart, Steregushchy...
You can learn many things about the world by watching others closely, Kapitan...
*ALARM*
Oh-hoh! My extra watch found the Rusalki first this time!
I guess all the sailors needed was the proper motivation, Steregushchy!
@BATTLE
What are you up to, Steregushchy? Scanning the horizon for Morgana bombers?
Nyet, Kapitan. I put extra sailors on watch again to make time for my hobby.
Your hobby? I don't mean to be rude, but I didn't think you had any hobbies aside from surveillance and reading...
Hey! If you think you know everything about me, you still need to observe a little more!
My apologies, Steregushchy! Please - do tell me about this hobby of yours.
Well, I have the teleskop to observe stars and planets, Kapitan. Then I look in my book about the kosmos to learn more about what I see.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, astronomy! I'd love to learn more about the stars!
Isn't the sky beautiful when you're out at sea? All the stars up there make our lives down here seem so... insignificant.
This "hobby" of yours sounds surprisingly similar to surveillance and reading...

Fields.DialogueText: I do not have time or equipment for proper astronomiya, Kapitan - but I enjoy watching the stars!
Oh-hoh, is the Kapitan a philosopher or a poet when off duty?
The sky is boring with no bombers on approach, so it is a good time to look at stars and read books on astronomiya!
Well, hopefully the giant observation binoculars you're going to build can serve double duty with your stargazing hobby.
Ha! Well, there's not much time for philosophy in the middle of battle with Morganas, that's for sure!
That's true. It's nice that you can find ways to entertain yourself and learn a bit on an otherwise dull watch.
Can you show me a planet or star through your telescope?
Da, Kapitan! I'm glad you are interested! Take a look through here... do you see Orion?
Hmm... that doesn't look like a constellation to me...
Oy, it is pointed straight at Orion's belt, Kapitan! Maybe the lens needs polishing...
The lens isn't dirty, Steregushchy - but all I can see out there are Morganas approaching! Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Steregushchy! I think this is the first time I've ever seen you in the mess hall.
I take meals in my observatoriya whenever possible, Kapitan. It is less of an interruption to my work.
I see. You do just about everything in that observatory pod of yours. Why are all these binoculars and telescopes on the tables?
Midshipman Antonova here is helping me polish the lenses on all my binokl and teleskopy.
Da, Kapitan! Comrade Steregushchy requires all of her observation equipment to be polished twice daily, with further deep cleaning every three days!
Steregushchy certainly does keep her gear clean. Are you always the one helping her with the polishing, Midshipman Antonova?
Da, Kapitan! My regular duty is in the ship's mess, but I'm not much help in here anyway. I don't mind assisting Comrade Steregushchy.
Da, Midshipman Antonova is a great assistant, Kapitan! She also brings pirozhki to me for meals in my observatoriya, and finds books I need when in port.

Fields.MenuText: It's great that the crew is working as a team to support each other!
It sounds like you've turned her into your own personal aide...
Shouldn't Midshipman Antonova pay more attention to her actual duties in the mess?

Fields.DialogueText: This is a Red Fleet ship, Kapitan! Mess standards are not so high anyway...
Da, Kapitan! We will crush the Rusalki with the strength of our numbers!
We are all working towards the same goal, Kapitan. We all win when the Rusalki are defeated!
Oh, seems like the next meal service is starting soon. You'll need to finish up all this polishing and clear off the tables to make room for the sailors to eat.
Da, Kapitan! I only have one more binokl to finish, and then I will clear off the tables.
It is hard to find help as good as her, Kapitan!
*BOOM*
I just wish we had better sailors on watch. Seems like the Morganas got the jump on us again!
The problem is bad surveillance equipment, not bad sailors!
@BATTLE
Even Belles need help sometimes.
We're halfway to Italy, Steregushchy. We'll get the silica sand you need for your binocular lenses soon enough!
Da, Kapitan. In the meantime, I want to practice glass making techniques I read about in my book, so I asked Midshipman Antonova to find some sand while we are in port.
Well, there's plenty of sand on the beach over there, but I'm pretty sure that's not the type of high quality sand you need.
The best sand for glass is pure silica sand, Kapitan. Beach sand is not so clean, but maybe okay just for practice glass making.
Comrade Steregushchy! I tried to find quality sand in the local market, but they had nothing. So all I could get was sand from the beach! Oy, these buckets of sand are so heavy!
Spasiba. We must make do with what is available.
Da, Comrade Steregushchy! Don't worry - with your amazing intelligence and hard work, I have no doubt you will build the biggest observation binokl in the history of the Red Fleet!

Fields.MenuText: Midshipman Antonova seems to be a big fan of yours, Steregushchy!
Is there anything Midshipman Antonova won't do for you?
Midshipman Antonova really wants to look good on her next fitness report, doesn't she?

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan! I appreciate her positive attitude whenever I need help. She is a strong Russian woman!
Midshipman Antonova is always happy to comply with my requests, Kapitan. I think she would do just about anything I ask of her...
Hey! Midshipman Antonova works hard for the mission, not just promotion, Kapitan!
Oh, look at the time! We need to get back on board since we're scheduled to depart soon.
You heard the Kapitan, Midshipman Antonova! Hurry up and get those buckets of sand on board!
Da, Comrade Steregushchy! I apologize for the delay - these buckets are quite heavy!
Intel shows Morganas approaching the harbor, Steregushchy. We're going to have to fight our way out of here!
@BATTLE
We need more heat from the boilers, Midshipman Antonova!
Da, Comrade Steregushchy! I am adding as much fuel as I can! Oof... it's so hot in here!
*CREEEAK*
Ah, there you are, Steregushchy! I wasn't expecting to find you down here in the engine room of all places...
Da, Kapitan. We are using heat from the boiler to melt down sand from the beach. It is a test run for glass making!
Well, it certainly seems hot enough for glass making in here! You and Midshipman Antonova are working up quite a sweat!
Da, Kapitan! We are getting very sweaty together!

Fields.MenuText: Your efforts will pay off once you make the biggest observation binoculars in the history of the Red Fleet!
You really do work Midshipman Antonova hard, don't you?
This isn't the first time you've gotten sweaty together, is it?

Fields.DialogueText: Da! We must all work together to defeat the Rusalki!
Midshipman Antonova fulfills her duties without complaint, Kapitan.
Hey! We do a lot of work together, Kapitan. I am not sure what else you are thinking...
Well, I wish you good luck with the glass making. You'll have to show me how it turns out later - I've got to get back to the bridge.
Do not worry, Kapitan. Glass making is proceeding according to plan!
Da, Kapitan! Comrade Steregushchy really knows what she's doing!
Add more fuel, Midshipman Antonova! It's still not hot enough in there to get the job done!
Da, Comrade Steregushchy! I will get it hot enough for you!
*BOOM*
Well, that's perfect timing for a Morgana attack, isn't it? That's enough heat for now - we need to get above deck and return fire!
@BATTLE
I hope your glass making turned out well, Steregushchy. Can you show me the lens you made?
T'fu! We made glass, Kapitan, but beach sand does not make good lenses!
Da, Kapitan! I tried to find good quality sand at last port, but could only find sand on the beach. It was not what Comrade Steregushchy needed...
The glass is very dark and very brown. There's no way to see Rusalki through a lens like this!

Fields.MenuText: You did manage to turn sand into glass. That's an impressive first step!
I'm sure you'll make a great binocular lens once you have the right quality sand.
Seems like all that sweating in the engine room just left you tired and frustrated!

Fields.DialogueText: I am very disappointed that I did not achieve my goal with Midshipman Antonova, Kapitan!
Da, Kapitan! It was a lot of hard work, but we learned better for next time!
Da, Kapitan. A meal can only be as good as the ingredients!
Going through the process was still good practice for when you finally get the silica sand you need.
The first pancake is always a blob, Kapitan. We will make improvements for next time.
Da, Comrade Steregushchy! Let us not give up yet - I know we can accomplish so much together!
*BOOM*
Those Morganas keep on getting the first shot! We really need better observation equipment, Steregushchy!
I have been saying this from the very start, Kapitan! Boyevyye stantsii!
@BATTLE
I'm sorry that the beach sand ruined your lens, Steregushchy.
Beach sand is not pure, Kapitan, so maybe brown glass is not a big surprise.
Well, I know you and Midshipman Antonova worked hard to make it, so it was a little disappointing that it didn't turn out how you wanted.
Oy, life is full of disappointments anyway, Kapitan.
You are quite the cynic, aren't you?
Ha! How can you sail with the Red Fleet and not be a cynic? I am just alone out here on the ocean with my binokl and teleskopy, watching and waiting...

Fields.MenuText: What are you waiting for, exactly?
You're not alone, Steregushchy - we're all in this together as one crew.
You sound like you either need more coffee or more sleep...

Fields.DialogueText: I am not sure, Kapitan. I always have a feeling that something bad is coming, so I have to keep watch to feel safe.
You talk like Soviet propaganda, Kapitan!
Aha... maybe, Kapitan. I only had three cups of coffee today, and am on my 12th hour of watch...
You seem down today, but don't be too hard on yourself, Steregushchy.
I am not feeling bad, Kapitan - I am just realistic. Making glass will be difficult. Winning the war will be difficult.
Just because something is difficult doesn't mean we shouldn't even try...
I did not say I will stop trying, Kapitan. I will build the biggest binokl in the history of the Red Fleet - and sink every Rusalki ship until there are no more floating!
That's the spirit!
*GUNFIRE*
If you want to sink every Morgana out there, we can start with these!
Da, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
What are all these charts on the tables, Steregushchy?
Midshipman Antonova is helping me update charts with latest intelligence on minefields.
Da, Kapitan! Comrade Steregushchy tells me it is very important to track the latest minefields laid by Rusalki!
That's very useful! Uncharted minefields could cost lives and ruin an entire operation. I'm glad you and Steregushchy are tracking them so closely.
Da, Kapitan! Don't worry - I may be a junior officer, but Steregushchy knows about everything and is teaching me so much!

Fields.MenuText: Midshipman Antonova is always so motivated, isn't she?
It's hard to find an officer of her caliber in any navy, let alone the Red Fleet!
She's always going on about how great you are, Steregushchy. Are you paying her to say these things?

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! She is very observant herself, Kapitan! She is free to think and say what she wishes... although we often agree.
Da, Kapitan. I do not really understand why, but her assistance is always welcome!
She is still young, Kapitan. Give her time, and she will soon be like all the others.
In any case, the Morganas have been laying a lot more mines lately. It's good that you two are tracking them.
To be honest, mines are a little boring, Kapitan. I prefer to watch for planes or ships, and submarines if needed. But mines? I leave those charts for her alone to update.
What makes mines so boring compared to anything else?
There is just something about them, Kapitan - big round balls with little knobs, just sitting there waiting to explode - that has never really piqued my interest.
I see.
*BOOM*
I think that explosion piqued everyone's interest! Battle stations!
@BATTLE
The chart says there's a minefield ahead, Kapitan. We should adjust course.
Thanks for pointing that out, Steregushchy - let's plot a new course around that minefield.
We are getting close to Italiya, aren't we?
Yes, we should be there by tomorrow. Once we arrive, you can get that high quality silica sand you need to make your binocular lenses.
Da, Kapitan. Then after Italiya, we need to chart course back to Rossiya to get steel for building binokl tubes.

Fields.MenuText: Not a problem. Building better observation gear is our greatest priority.
Do we really need to sail all the way back to Russia just to get steel?
You've been spending all your time learning glass making - have you read any books on metalworking?

Fields.DialogueText: I already know the basics of metalworking, Kapitan. I did build the observatoriya myself, remember?
We will not be surprised by Rusalki once we improve our surveillance gear, Kapitan!
Da, Kapitan. Why are necessary items for crafting always placed so far apart?
Well, we won't be spending very long in Italy - just long enough get your silica sand.
I'll have to grab a quick meal in the local piazza and enjoy the good food and weather before we immediately turn around and head back to Russia.
Hey! Cuisine in Matushka Rossiya is just as good as Italiya! Weather, on the other hand, is a different story...
The nice thing about being on a ship is that if you don't like where you are, you can always sail somewhere else.
Da, Kapitan, but even ships have to return home some day...
*GUNFIRE*
Rusalki in the harbor, Kapitan! One more battle before you can enjoy pasta and coffee in the piazza!
@BATTLE
Looks like you've finally got that silica sand you need for your binocular lenses, Steregushchy!
Da, Kapitan! Midshipman Antonova was able to find high-quality sand in the local market.
I could not get a lot because of war shortage, but it should be just enough for what we need, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure you'll have no problem making these lenses now that you have the right kind of sand.
Looks like you only have enough sand for one chance at this. No pressure.
Just enough sand for one try? Don't mess up like you did last time.

Fields.DialogueText: The procedure was correct last time, Kapitan, but the only problem was bad material. I am confident we will succeed this time!
Comrades of the Fleet never fail under pressure, Kapitan!
Why are you suddenly doubting, Kapitan? I will be happy to prove you wrong!
I have finished loading sand on board, Comrade Steregushchy! I cannot wait to go down to the engine room and make glass with you again!
Your assistance is always appreciated, Midshipman Antonova. Now it is time to return to Rossiya to get steel for binokl tubes!
Well, we've got Morganas on the horizon, so get ready for a fight on our way out of here!
@BATTLE
It is still not hot enough! Add more fuel to the boiler, Midshipman Antonova!
Oy! It is never hot enough for you, Comrade Steregushchy! Oof, I am already so sweaty!
We only get one chance at this! There is no room for error, so I need your full attention!
Da, Comrade Steregushchy!
*CREEEAK*
Ah, there you are, Steregushchy! I just came to check in on your glass making.
Now is not a good time for interruption, Kapitan! This is a very delicate moment in the glass making process!

Fields.MenuText: My apologies! I'll just watch quietly while you melt down that sand.
Oh, a delicate moment? What exactly am I interrupting?
If you and Midshipman Antonova are working up a sweat in the engine room, I'm curious to know more!

Fields.DialogueText: Spasiba, Kapitan! I will be with you in just a moment!
Zamolchi, Kapitan! It is a very delicate moment!
Now is not a good time for your curiosity, Kapitan. Please give us a moment to finish our work...
I didn't mean to get in the way! I'll just watch quietly from here.
It is working, Comrade Steregushchy!
Da! You managed to get it hot enough, Midshipman Antonova! Look at it melting!
*ALARM*
I've got to get back to the bridge, but it looks like you two have everything under control down here.
Da, Kapitan! The glass still needs to cool and be ground and polished into lenses, but the hard part is over!
I'll come back and check in on your progress after we take care of these Morganas.
I will expect another interruption from you soon then, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Here they are, Kapitan - the lenses for the biggest observation binokl in the history of the Red Fleet!
They're so big... and round! That's the most massive set of lenses I've ever seen!
Size is very important for binokl lenses, Kapitan, but clarity of lenses also makes a critical difference!
Da, Kapitan! The pure silica sand we used this time resulted in perfectly clear glass! There is nothing that Comrade Steregushchy cannot do!

Fields.MenuText: It's great to have Steregushchy on our side. The Morganas don't stand a chance against her!
Well, it was a team effort! She wouldn't have achieved anything without your sweat and hard work!
There are plenty of things Steregushchy can't do - like go a day without coffee, or sleep for more than 5 hours.

Fields.DialogueText: This is only further evidence of her tireless work ethic, Kapitan!
I consider myself lucky to serve with her, Kapitan!
We can always achieve more with help, Kapitan, but it is her genius and leadership that carries us in the right direction!
In any case, great work, Steregushchy! Our next stop is Russia to pick up the steel you need for the binocular housing.
Spasiba, Kapitan. In the meantime, we need to polish the lenses a little more for optimal clarity.
I am always happy to help you polish your lenses, Comrade Steregushchy! Whatever help you need - I am here to assist you!
*BOOM*
I can't wait for you to finish these binoculars, Steregushchy! These Morgana surprise attacks never seem to stop!
Surprise is always bad, Kapitan - but we have big guns to answer with too!
@BATTLE
Ah, Russia! We can finally pick up that steel you need, Steregushchy.
Da, Kapitan...
Are you feeling okay? Something seems a little off about you.
It is nothing, Kapitan. It is just... the first time back in Matushka Rossiya in a long time for me.
Aren't you happy to be back home?
I sail for the Red Fleet, Kapitan, but Rossiya is always fighting with itself more than with enemies outside. It makes me sad. We could be such a great nation...

Fields.MenuText: Russia is a great nation, Steregushchy. It just needs more great leaders like you to change things.
Every country has problems, but if we don't solve this Morgana crisis together, we're all going to lose.
The worst disasters are always the ones that mankind creates for itself...

Fields.DialogueText: I hope life will improve someday, but it will be difficult to change the way things are, Kapitan.
Da, Kapitan - you are right. We must focus on the crisis in front of us before placing our hopes on another useless revolution.
Da, Kapitan - although I'm sure the Rusalki are evil spirits sent by some force more powerful than us.
I didn't mean to get so serious, Steregushchy, but my point is we shouldn't be so cynical. We've got the power to change things and win this war.
Da, Kapitan. I will remember your words. It just seems like Rossiya keeps repeating the same mistakes over and over...
Comrade Steregushchy! I've got what we need - 100% authentic Russkaya steel! We can finally build the biggest observation binokl in the history of the Red Fleet!
Spasiba, Midshipman Antonova. Spasiba - you gave me exactly what I needed!
Time to get back out to sea, Steregushchy - we've got Morganas to fight.
Da, Kapitan. The nice thing about being on a ship is if you don't like where you are, you can always sail somewhere else...
@BATTLE
Wow, that was fast work with your Russian steel, Steregushchy!
Metalworking is much easier than glass making for me, Kapitan! The steel binokl housing is now complete with two binokl tubes!
Does the steel not look beautiful, Kapitan? Comrade Steregushchy made the binokl tubes with minimal sweating this time!
That's good to hear. All that glass making in the engine room seemed a lot more tiring.
Da, Kapitan! It got very hot in the engine room, so I appreciate a sea breeze while doing metalworking on deck.
So what's left to complete your binoculars, Steregushchy?
Polishing the lens and fitting it into the housing. After that, my binokl will be fully complete!

Fields.MenuText: Once we deploy your new binoculars, we'll spot those Morganas long before they're even in range!
What's your next project after this one?
Do you really think this thing will make any difference in how we fight the Morganas?

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan! Our surveillance capabilities will be greatly increased! Although there will still be room for improvement...
That is a good question, Kapitan. Maybe something to help detect bombers - they're only getting trickier.
Of course, Kapitan! Those who strike first win!
Well, I can't wait to see your finished observation binoculars after all this time and effort!
We are making some last adjustments, but the binokl will be ready to show by tomorrow.
*BOOM*
Those binoculars can't get here soon enough, Steregushchy! Return fire!
@BATTLE
It is difficult work adjusting for the tossing of the waves, but the caffeine vibration cancels it out quite handily.
I'm surprised you can work with something as delicate as glass out here.
I brought a cup of coffee for you, Kapitan.
Thank you, Steregushchy. I know you've been working hard on this binocular project of yours. You've certainly gone through a lot of cups of coffee in the process.
Coffee consumption remains consistent, Kapitan, although I regret that my time in the engine room took away from time keeping watch in my observatoriya.
It will all be worth it if these binoculars work as planned.
Da, Kapitan, but the Rusalki ambushed us several times because I was not on watch. It only takes one lucky shot to sink a ship, so I must always be watching...

Fields.MenuText: I know you're doing your best, Steregushchy. That's all I could ever ask of you.
The sailors are keeping watch too. It's a team effort, so don't put all the responsibility on your shoulders.
I've noticed on Sundays you like to get an extra hour of sleep. You're not the only one doing the watching around here!

Fields.DialogueText: My apologies, Kapitan! I try not to waste time on sleep, but sometimes it catches up with me!
Trying my best is not good enough if a Rusalki bomber makes a surprise attack on the ship, Kapitan!
Sailors are not as good at surveillance as I am, Kapitan. I need to be on watch for maximum effectiveness.
If only there was more than one of you, Steregushchy - we could get a lot more done around here.
I am sorry to disappoint you with my performance, Kapitan.
I meant that as a compliment, not as a criticism.
*ALARM*
Sounds like our sailors spotted the Rusalki first this time, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
So what do you think, Kapitan?
It is the biggest observation binokl in the history of the Red Fleet, Kapitan! Comrade Steregushchy did it!
I don't know what to say! It's gigantic... and beautiful! The way the light catches off those crystal clear lenses and the shiny steel housing is just astounding!
Initial testing has shown an exponential increase in clarity and range compared to standard issue Soviet binokl, Kapitan.
That doesn't suprise me! These lenses are so enormous, I bet you could spot Pluto in the night sky!
The main purpose is spotting Rusalki, Kapitan, but you are right - it will also be useful for my stargazing hobby!

Fields.MenuText: Well, I'm certain these are the largest observation binoculars in the Red Fleet.
These might even be the largest binoculars in the entire Neutrality Fleet!
Maybe you should give up fighting and open your own scientific observatory instead.

Fields.DialogueText: I am not sure which is more dangerous - being in the military or being a scientist. Politicians only like academics when they do not think too much...
They are the biggest, but they owe their clarity to Midshipman Antonova and her sand skills!
Perhaps, Kapitan. Other navies have more modern surveillance equipment compared to the Red Fleet, though...
I'd like to take a look through these binoculars if you don't mind, Steregushchy...
Of course, Kapitan! I hope you are satisfied.
Aren't you amazed by what you can see, Kapitan? Comrade Steregushchy is such an impressive--
Morganas! We've got a whole Morgana armada coming over the horizon and heading straight for us!
Oh-hoh! Are you sure, Kapitan?
What do you mean? Of course I'm sure! I'm looking through the biggest observation binoculars in the history of the Red Fleet!
@BATTLE
Can you spot any more Morganas through your binoculars, Steregushchy?
Da, Kapitan! We sank that first wave, but there are still more coming!
We have taken much damage from last encounter, Kapitan! I will direct the fire suppression!
Thanks, Midshipman Antonova! The ship needs your leadership right now - make sure the sailors keep the fires from spreading!
I am relaying the locations of incoming enemies to the conning tower, Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: We need our guns firing as soon as the targets are in range!
We'll win this battle if we keep working together!
There's just too many of them...

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan!
Just make sure we are firing everything we have, Kapitan! There are many of them coming...
Now is the time to focus on our mission, Kapitan! The ship and the crew need you to lead them!
This isn't going to be easy, but we can get through this if we make every shot count!
We have fires burning fore and aft, Kapitan!
Get them under control immediately, Antonova!
More Rusalki closing in, Kapitan!
*GUNFIRE*
@BATTLE
Another wave of Rusalki approaching, Kapitan!
There's no end to them! How many Morganas can there be in this fleet?
Not sure, Kapitan. I can only see as far as the horizon - but the horizon is full of Rusalki!
I will head to the stern to help sailors put out fires, Kapitan!
Thanks, Midshipman Antonova! It seems worse back there than the fire on the bow...
*GUNFIRE*
Guns are hitting the Rusalki as soon as I spot them, Kapitan!
Keep it up!
There's a Morgana bomber right  overhead, Steregushchy!
Where, Kapitan? I must not have spotted it approaching--

Fields.MenuText: It's flying over our stern!
It's right above the crew putting out that fire...
How did you let that bomber get this close to us?

Fields.DialogueText: Midshipman Antonova just ran back there to help put out fires!
Midshipman Antonova just ran back there to help them!
I can't watch everything at once, Kapitan! Midshipman Antonova just ran back there to help put out fires!
*BOOM*
@BATTLE
This is the last of the Rusalki, Kapitan!
We can go check on Midshipman Antonova after we've finished off these damn Morganas!
@BATTLE
I cannot look, Kapitan! I am so afraid! How is she?
Midshipman Antonova was pretty close to where the bomb hit, but she's still breathing. There's a little blood, but I think she'll be okay once she comes to.
Oh! I am relieved, Kapitan! This was all my fault - I was not watching closely and the bomber slipped through...
You're always too hard on yourself, Steregushchy. It's not your job alone to handle every problem that comes your way.

Fields.MenuText: That's why we have friends.
I care about you more than all the stars and planets in the sky! I'll always be here to protect you.

Fields.DialogueText: What kind of friend am I when I cannot even keep Midshipman Antonova safe from Rusalki?
That is very strange thing to say to the Comrade of the Fleet, Kapitan. Blagodaryu vas.
Oh look! Midshipman Antonova is opening her eyes!
Comrade... Steregushchy!
